title: 110_s2812
content: The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008, also known as the Act, includes provisions such as an increase in the number of types of originating sites and the expansion of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services. It aims to improve the process for updating the list of telehealth services. The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008 expands the types of originating sites eligible for telehealth services, including skilled nursing facilities, renal dialysis facilities, mental health centers, and other sites with a telecommunications system. Additionally, certain originating sites are exempt from facility fees. The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008 expands eligible originating sites for telehealth services, exempting certain sites from facility fees. No facility fee is required for specific originating sites, with no impact on payment to distant sites. The amendments apply to services provided 90 days after the Act's enactment. Expansion of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services. Expansion of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services includes an amendment to the Social Security Act, broadening the definition of a practitioner to include physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech-language pathologists, audiologists, and certified providers. The amendment to the Social Security Act expands the list of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services, including physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech-language pathologists, audiologists, and certified providers. The effective date for these amendments is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendment to the Social Security Act expands the list of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services, including physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech-language pathologists, audiologists, and certified providers. The effective date for these amendments is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is a provision for the improvement of the process for updating the list of telehealth services. The Social Security Act is amended to include a Telehealth Advisory Committee to make recommendations on adding or deleting services and HCPCS codes. The Secretary must consider the Committee's recommendations, and if not implemented, provide a reason in the Federal Register. The Telehealth Advisory Committee, composed of 7 members appointed by the Secretary, includes practicing physicians and non-physician health care providers with experience in telemedicine or telehealth. The Telehealth Advisory Committee members must have experience in telemedicine or telehealth, represent a balance of specialties and regions, and consider stakeholder recommendations. They serve terms specified by the Secretary, meet twice a year, and are exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary can establish the committee despite administrative limitations. The Advisory Committee will be established without any restrictions on the number of advisory committees that can be formed within the Department of Health and Human Services or elsewhere.
